bioghist.p: Eastern State Penitentiary opened in 1829 and was designed by John Haviland. Its revolutionary system of incarceration, dubbed the Pennsylvania System, originated and encouraged solitary confinement as a form of rehabilitation. Eastern State's radial floor plan and system of solitary confinement became the model for over 300 prisons worldwide. Eastern State was viewed as a progressive reform in that it eliminated many of the excesses of physical punishment in colonial America. Despite this, it was widely believed (then and now) to have caused significant mental illness among its prisoners due to its solitary confinement. The system quickly collapsed due to overcrowding problems. By 1913, Eastern State officially abandoned the solitary system and operated as a congregate prison until it closed in 1970.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of three volumes of patient information kept at the infirmary of the Eastern States Penitentiary from 1840 to 1868. The volumes present monthly summaries of cases, and provide some remarks based on post mortem examinations. The earliest volume (1840-1843) gives daily tallies of patients, their diseases, and the progress of their diseases. The volume includes monthly summaries of patients, with a separate tally for African-American patients. In this volume there are also yearly tabular views of the cases of African-American prisoners and one tabular view of the cases of white prisoners in 1841. The other two volumes (1844-1855 and 1855-1868) consist of monthly summaries of patients, their diseases, race, gender, and progress of the diseases. These two volumes also include postmortem reports.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
